message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage, and an enlarged, soft uterus suggests uterine atony. The most appropriate next step would be to perform bimanual uterine massage to stimulate uterine contractions and control bleeding. Methylergometrine can be used if bimanual uterine massage is not effective, but it should not be used without confirming that the patient does not have hypertension or other contraindications. Curettage with suctioning and tranexamic acid are not appropriate first-line management for postpartum hemorrhage with uterine atony.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest postpartum hemorrhage, and the enlarged, soft uterus indicates uterine atony, which is the most common cause. The first priority is to perform bimanual uterine massage to help the uterus contract and reduce bleeding. Methylergometrine can also help with uterine contraction, but since the diagnosis is not confirmed, it should not be administered yet. Curettage with suctioning may be needed if the bleeding does not stop with massage or medication, but it is not the first-line treatment. Tranexamic acid can help stop bleeding, but it takes time to work and is not the first-line treatment in this emergency situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has postpartum hemorrhage and an enlarged uterus, so bimanual uterine massage is the most appropriate first step in management to control bleeding. Methylergometrine, curettage with suctioning, and tranexamic acid can be considered if bleeding continues after bimanual uterine massage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage and has an enlarged, soft uterus, which indicates that it is not contracted well. Bimanual uterine massage is the first-line management to encourage uterine contraction and control bleeding. Methylergometrine is a uterotonic drug used for postpartum hemorrhage, but it should not be given until the uterus has been fully contracted. Curettage with suctioning is not indicated in this situation. Tranexamic acid may be used as an adjunct therapy but bimanual uterine massage is the first and most important step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage, likely due to atony of the uterus. Bimanual uterine massage is the first-line therapy for this condition, followed by pharmacologic interventions if necessary. Methylergometrine is a uterotonic agent that can be used if massage alone is not effective. Curettage with suctioning is not appropriate in this case as there is no indication for retained products of conception. Tranexamic acid is used to treat bleeding disorders but is not indicated in the management of postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage, which could be caused by a retained placenta or uterine atony. Since physical exam shows an enlarged, soft uterus, uterine atony is more likely, and bimanual uterine massage can help stimulate uterine contractions and control bleeding. Methylergometrine can also be used for uterine atony, but it is contraindicated in patients with hypertension. Curettage with suctioning is not appropriate for this situation, and tranexamic acid can be used as an adjunct therapy but not as the primary method of management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage with an enlarged, soft uterus, indicating uterine atony. The most appropriate next step is bimanual uterine massage to manually compress the uterus and control bleeding. Methylergometrine can be used if uterine massage is ineffective, but it should be avoided in patients with hypertension, and the patient’s blood pressure is not provided. Curettage with suctioning is not indicated as the source of bleeding is uterine atony, not retained products of conception. Tranexamic acid can be used as adjunctive therapy but is not the first-line treatment for controlling bleeding in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest postpartum hemorrhage, and an enlarged, soft uterus indicates uterine atony. Therefore, the most appropriate next step would be bimanual uterine massage to help stimulate contractions and control bleeding. Methylergometrine can also aid in uterine contractions, but it can increase blood pressure and should be avoided if the patient has hypertension or preeclampsia. Curettage with suctioning is not indicated in this case as it is more appropriate for managing retained products of conception. Tranexamic acid is used to promote blood clotting and control bleeding but is typically reserved for more severe cases of postpartum hemorrhage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has postpartum hemorrhage, which is a medical emergency. The most appropriate first step in management is bimanual uterine massage to stimulate contraction and control bleeding. Methylergometrine can be given after the uterus is contracted. Curettage with suctioning is not appropriate as the patient has no retained placental tissue. Tranexamic acid can be used in conjunction with other measures to control bleeding, but it is not the initial step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage and has an enlarged, soft uterus, suggesting that the bleeding is due to uterine atony (failure of the uterus to contract). The most appropriate next step in management is bimanual uterine massage, which can help stimulate uterine contractions and control bleeding. Methylergometrine can also be used to stimulate uterine contractions, but it should be avoided in patients with hypertension. Curettage with suctioning is not indicated in this situation, and Tranexamic acid can be used to reduce bleeding but is not the first-line treatment for postpartum hemorrhage.
